Award.AwardTitle: Liquefaction Evaluations of Finely Interlayered Sands, Silts and Clays

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Recent earthquakes, including the 2010-2011 Canterbury Earthquake Sequence (CES) in New Zealand (NZ), have shown that current engineering procedures have a strong tendency to over-predict liquefaction effects in thinly interlayered sand, silt, and clay deposits. This was observed in the Riccarton area in Christchurch, NZ where minimal damage occurred, but various engineering analyses predicted that at least one of the 2010-11 CES events should have caused significant ground surface damage due to liquefaction of the soils between depths of 1 and 10 m. The over-prediction of liquefaction effects in these types of deposits is a major concern in engineering practice worldwide because it leads to potentially unnecessary and expensive ground improvement or structural strengthening efforts. This research will contribute to eliminating this bias in current liquefaction evaluation procedures by addressing fundamental limitations associated with: (1) insufficient stratigraphic resolution with cone penetrometer measurements, (2) biases in the liquefaction triggering models for intermediate soil types, and (3) insufficient accounting of spatial variability in the analysis models used to estimate ground deformations. The development of improved methods for interpreting cone penetration measurements and accounting for geologic variability has broad applicability and benefit to the geotechnical profession. The correction of over-prediction biases in liquefaction procedures will contribute to more realistic risk assessments and improved land use planning for communities. The collaboration with NZ researchers will enable direct implementation of results in the Christchurch area and thereby contribute to more efficient rebuilding efforts. The student training and module development will increase the exposure of civil engineering to girls and the enhanced mentoring of our graduate student group will foster more diverse and engaged leaders in industry and academia.

This research will address a major limitation in current liquefaction evaluation procedures by seeking to eliminate the strong bias toward over-predicting liquefaction effects in finely interlayered sand, silt and clay deposits. The first task will use physical modeling on a geotechnical centrifuge and axisymmetric numerical simulations of the cone penetration process to refine procedures for using cone penetration test (CPT) data to delineate stratigraphic layering and material types. The second task will update a CPT-based liquefaction triggering model using recent field data from New Zealand with improved mechanics-based functional forms for intermediate soil types. The third task will use nonlinear dynamic analyses with spatially correlated geostatistical realizations of subsurface stratigraphy to examine how one-dimensional liquefaction vulnerability indices, with their inherent assumption of horizontal layering, are biased toward over-predicting earthquake-induced ground deformations in these types of deposits. The fourth task will reevaluate the performance of Riccarton sites in the 2010-11 CES using findings from tasks one through three, and evaluate the extent to which those findings resolve the differences between the predicted and observed performances of the Riccarton area in these different earthquake events. This research will thereby integrate experimental, theoretical, and case history findings toward resolving fundamental issues affecting liquefaction evaluations, with the broader findings regarding the interpretation of cone penetration test data in finely interlayered soils and the representation of spatial variability in ground deformation models also having potentially major impacts on general practice.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The intellectual merits of this project included new methods, algorithms, software, and scientific understandings that contribute to improved evaluations of earthquake-induced ground deformations in interlayered deposits of saturated sands, silts, and clays. An inverse filtering method was conceived, developed, and implemented that provides the first known method for automatically correcting cone penetration test data for measurement errors near soil interfaces or in thin interlayers. Cone penetration tests in physical models on a 9-m radius geotechnical centrifuge filled data gaps on how interface measurement errors vary with the contrast in soil properties and cone penetrometer diameter, which provided validation for the underlying theory for the inverse filtering method. The inverse filtering method provides a rational means for avoiding the conservative bias that cone penetration test data exhibit in interlayered deposits (i.e., underestimating soil strengths), which contributes to the known tendency for subsequent analyses to overestimate earthquake-induced ground deformations. A new constitutive model called PM4Silt was developed and implemented that provides improved simulation of how clays and silts respond during earthquake loading, which combined with existing constitutive models for sands, enables improved numerical simulations of the nonlinear dynamic response of interlayered soil deposits during earthquakes. Nonlinear dynamic analyses of well-documented cases histories from past earthquakes involving interlayered deposits demonstrated key interaction mechanisms not previously identified or appreciated. The presence of laterally discontinuous clay lenses were shown to influence how excess pore pressures diffuse after liquefaction has been triggered, with the consequence that the upward seepage is amplified near the ends of the clay lenses, resulting in a concentration of sand boils, whereas seepage is suppressed above the clay lenses, resulting in an absence of sand boils. Appreciation of this mechanism is essential for guiding researchers in interpreting how surface manifestations of liquefaction may correlate with subsurface soil properties. The use of conditional transition probability methods for describing interlayered deposits provided insights on how the patterns of earthquake-induced ground deformation are affected by the depositional characteristics or geomorphology of a deposit.  Collectively, the products and findings from these studies improved our scientific understanding of the various factors that have contributed to the general bias of common engineering procedures to overestimate earthquake-induced ground deformations in interlayered deposits.

This broader impacts of this project include advances that will improve engineering assessments and management of seismic risks for civil infrastructure and society, technical advances that are broadly applicable to non-seismic aspects of geotechnical engineering, and contributions to the development of a diverse and engaged engineering workforce. The collective results of this project provide a basis for reducing the general bias of common engineering procedures to overestimate ground deformations in interlayered deposits during earthquakes, which will enable more economical solutions and more efficient use of resources in reducing seismic risks. The inverse filtering procedure for improved and automated interpretation of cone penetration test measurements in interlayered soils that has broad applicability for non-seismic problems across the geotechnical profession, as does the demonstrated application of conditional transition probability methods for representing interlayered soil deposits in engineering analyses. This project supported research by one post-doctoral researcher (now an assistant professor), two doctoral students who have graduated (both women, one an assistant professor), one continuing doctoral student, and two masters students. These researchers were mentored on outreach practices and guided in taking on leadership roles in professional and student society organizations, through which they led a wide range of outreach activities targeting the public, K-12 groups, REU students, undergraduate student competitions, and practicing professionals.  

 


Last Modified: 11/18/2020
Modified by: Ross W Boulanger
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The intellectual merits of this project included new methods, algorithms, software, and scientific understandings that contribute to improved evaluations of earthquake-induced ground deformations in interlayered deposits of saturated sands, silts, and clays. An inverse filtering method was conceived, developed, and implemented that provides the first known method for automatically correcting cone penetration test data for measurement errors near soil interfaces or in thin interlayers. Cone penetration tests in physical models on a 9-m radius geotechnical centrifuge filled data gaps on how interface measurement errors vary with the contrast in soil properties and cone penetrometer diameter, which provided validation for the underlying theory for the inverse filtering method. The inverse filtering method provides a rational means for avoiding the conservative bias that cone penetration test data exhibit in interlayered deposits (i.e., underestimating soil strengths), which contributes to the known tendency for subsequent analyses to overestimate earthquake-induced ground deformations. A new constitutive model called PM4Silt was developed and implemented that provides improved simulation of how clays and silts respond during earthquake loading, which combined with existing constitutive models for sands, enables improved numerical simulations of the nonlinear dynamic response of interlayered soil deposits during earthquakes. Nonlinear dynamic analyses of well-documented cases histories from past earthquakes involving interlayered deposits demonstrated key interaction mechanisms not previously identified or appreciated. This broader impacts of this project include advances that will improve engineering assessments and management of seismic risks for civil infrastructure and society, technical advances that are broadly applicable to non-seismic aspects of geotechnical engineering, and contributions to the development of a diverse and engaged engineering workforce. The collective results of this project provide a basis for reducing the general bias of common engineering procedures to overestimate ground deformations in interlayered deposits during earthquakes, which will enable more economical solutions and more efficient use of resources in reducing seismic risks.
